name: 4-hydroxypyridine
Reason: The basic unit, pyridine, has a melting point of around 5.5°C. The addition of a hydroxyl (-OH) group to the pyridine ring will increase the melting point due to the formation of strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Hydrogen bonds significantly increase the energy required to melt a compound, and a hydroxyl group could elevate the melting point by around 140°C because of the strong hydrogen bonding it introduces. Moreover, the attachment of the -OH group to a nitrogen-containing heterocycle further increases the melting point by enhancing molecular rigidity and polarity.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, pyridine has a melting point of around 110°C. 
- Hydroxyl group (-OH): This group can form hydrogen bonds, which typically increases the melting point. The effect of a hydroxyl group on the melting point of a compound can be significant, potentially adding around +40°C to the melting point. 
- The presence of the hydroxyl group also introduces the possibility of intermolecular hydrogen bonding, which can further increase the melting point.
